resources.string: How accurately do I need to measure?

The App itself is accurate to one centimeter or 3/8 imperial inches.\n\nYou can use the app to get the measurements sufficiently close to then be able to align the tent according to the manufacturers instructions.
How do I get the app to match my measurements?

When you tap the label halfway between the trees, the app should open an interface for fine-tuning its value.\n\nDo not worry about entering a more precise value than this app allows. Less precise measurements are likely close enough for what you need to setup. Use this App to get close enough to follow the manufacturers instructions.
What if my measurement goes off the screen?

Depending on the issue, you have a few options. You can... 

... drag the tether intersection point (if visible) to move all the anchors simultaneously. 

... rotate the configuration (when tent is drawn) by dragging a point that is not part of the configuration. 

... tilt the device and modify anchors in that orientation. 

... reset the anchors using the menu option. 

... change the scale of the units using the slider.
Do I need to know how thick the tree is?

You do not need to know where the center of the tree is. Instead, imagine a knot on the surface of each tree about where the tent tether would attach. Measure the distance from the imaginary knot on one tree to the imaginary knot on the next anchoring tree, etc.
You are measuring the distances between approximate locations of the knots.
Why is my tent not in the list?
Try dragging the list to see tents that are not in view. Otherwise, if it is a newer product, we may need to add it. In the meantime try using a tent or hammock with a similar \"footprint\" as yours.

It helps to have a measuring tool handy, such as measuring tape or laser measuring tool. But, you could perform the measurements using consistently-spaced units, such as equally-spaced knots in a (low-stretch) string, sufficiently consistent paces, or even the straps that come with the tent. The point here is to measure using consistent units.
What does the orange triangle indicate?

The orange triangle indicates that setup is possible, but involves a non-intuitive "trick".

With the ratchet detached from the tent, simultaneously pass the ratchet through the strap loop and the strap through the ratchet loop to cinch them together. Then pass the strap through the tent D-ring, around the tree, and into the ratchet. Tighten as usual.

Alternatively, with the ratchet attached to the tent D-ring, pass the ratchet through the strap loop. Then wrap the strap around the tree and into the ratchet. Tighten as usual.
What does the yellow triangle indicate?

The yellow triangle indicates that you will not have sufficient strap length to wrap around the tree according to recommendations.\n\nSetup using trees requires an extension or tree-protector strap for the tree with this symbol over it.
What does the red X indicate?
The red X indicates that (ideal) setup is not possible. \n\nThe tree with the red X over it is too close.
How do I close this FAQ page?
Press the back button to close this page.
What are the small circles shown on the tethers?
The small circles are supposed to represent transition points, where the tethers change. For example, the tent corners, ratchets, and straps.
Do I still need to use the tabs on the sides of my tent?
That would be best. This app tries to get you close to the point where you can then align the tethers with the sight-indicator tabs on the sides of the non-equal-sided tents and hammocks.
